thread.title: Baylor football responsible for 52 rapes by 31 players: lawsuit
thread.title_full: Baylor football responsible for 52 rapes by 31 players: lawsuit | New York Post

author: Hannah Withiam
title: Baylor football responsible for 52 rapes by 31 players: lawsuit
text:
The accusations against the Baylor football program reached a horrifying new level Friday when a former graduate student filed a lawsuit alleging 31 players were responsible for 52 incidents of rape, including five gang rapes, from 2011 to 2014, according to the Dallas Morning News .
At least two of the gang rapes involved 10 or more players at one time, the lawsuit claims.
The woman’s lawyers said they reached those figures based on an investigation into reports filed over the period of four years.
The numbers far surpass those offered by Baylor regents in a recent report published by the Wall Street Journal . Baylor officials said 17 women reported rapes committed by 19 players, including four gang rapes, since 2011.
The woman, who is suing Baylor for Title IX violations, claims she was gang raped by football players Tre’Von Armstead and Shamycheal Chatman following a campus party in 2013. She says Chatman was previously accused of rape by a student athletic trainer, but instead of punishing him the university offered to reassign the victim to a female athletic team if she would keep the incident under wraps.
According to the lawsuit, Baylor football promoted a “show ’em a good time” culture and “used sex to sell” the school to recruits.
Former assistant coach Kendall Briles allegedly asked a high school recruit, “Do you like white women? Because we have a lot of them at Baylor and they love football players.” Briles is the son of head coach Art Briles — who was fired by Baylor last year amid mounting evidence of a rape culure around the football team — and recently was hired as offensive coordinator by Lane Kiffin at Florida Atlantic.
The most recent allegations come after former university president Ken Starr, also deposed in the fallout from the scandal, told the Wall Street Journal in December he personally “doubts that there were gang rapes.”
